conclusion: Problem involves shadows of objects labeled A, B, C, and D with a light source above them.
Question asks what happens to shadows when light source moves backward above the objects.
Need to consider both position and size of shadows.
Understanding 'backward' as moving away from objects, possibly higher up or farther horizontally.
Exact direction of 'backward' isn't specified, general movement away from objects.
Shadows are cast on the opposite side from the light source.
Position of shadow depends on position of light source relative to object.
If light source moves farther away, shadows become smaller and closer to objects.
Angle at which light rays hit objects changes with distance of light source.
Closer light source results in longer, more spread out shadows.
Farther light source results in more perpendicular light rays, shorter and tighter shadows.
Sun's position results in sharp, not very blurred shadows.
Far away light source results in sharper, closer shadows.
Light source is above objects and moving backward, similar to sun's position.
Shadows should become sharper and smaller.
Object A's shadow should move closer and become smaller.
Object B's shadow should get smaller and closer.
Object C's shadow should undergo similar changes.
Object D's shadow should become smaller and closer.
Considering exact directions of light source movement.
If light source moves backward directly above, shadows should move accordingly.
